topics.body:
"@someguy111":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/537d979b6368721c08200000#post_537d979b6368721c08200000
Then you miss the entire point of de-extinction. They are bringing these species back so they can restore the ecosystems they belonged too. Since most of the candidates have only been extinct for the past hundred or two hundred years, it will do little to no environmental damage.

And who doesn't want a pet frog that raises its babies in its stomach? It would be the best pet for vore fetishists!

topics.body:
"@trashboat":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/537d9ab16368725558430000#post_537d9ab16368725558430000
Who the fuck goes near a beehive in the first place? If I saw any beehive, I would keep a very good distance regardless of species.
topics.author: 50b70eeb7f123b1a02000097

topics.body:
"@gasmaskangel":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/537d987263687218da9d0000#post_537d987263687218da9d0000
I don't doubt the benefits of things like that but you must remember it's a two-way street. There is a line to be drawn between helping the world and playing God. 


"@Randomosaur":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/537d98986368721a889a0000#post_537d98986368721a889a0000
Putting a species back into an environment it has been absent from for even 100 years may not work out so well; nature has adapted to go on without it and the sudden reintroduction could have bad consequences. Who is to say there will enough food for it to survive? Will there be enough habitat for it? Keep in mind that the creature went extinct and went extinct for a reason, even if that reason was man made, it was wiped out because it could not survive, now we are going to put it back in an environment which may not even have enough room for it? Keeping these kinds of things as pets could be cool but keep in mind all it takes is one stupid kid to let his pet go and suddenly you have tons of little frogs everywhere that could cause an issue to an environment that is not adapted to handle them as they have been extinct for quite some time.
topics.author: 5010fa077f123b1e4f00104e

topics.body:
"@someguy111":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/537d9d5a63687226790b0000#post_537d9d5a63687226790b0000
The reason why the thylacine, heath hen, Pyrenean ibex and aurochs were wiped out is man. I doubt we will wipe them out again if we put in strict laws to protect them.

The cause of the gastric-brooding frog's extinction is still unknown, but it was probably chytrid fungus, which is wiping out amphibians worldwide.
topics.author: 50b70eeb7f123b1a02000097

topics.body:
in my personal opinion i think people exagerate extinction sometimes.

i mean if their species went extinct that means they just couldnt werent fit to survive, and isnt that what darwing theory was about?.

i mean what if the next animal species evolve to become more resistant against humans and thus make their species survive more easily?

im talking out off my ass in this of course, im no biologist.

Oh, then you don't know of this then.
!http://biogeodb.stri.si.edu/bioinformatics/dfmfiles/files/d/42091/42091.jpg!

Perisceptis Carnivora. Just a normal moth when it has become a moth, but before that, it's arguably the most sadistic larva. It will eat other insects alive, then proceed to put together a camouflage from the _leftover decomposing corpse_.

!http://biogeodb.stri.si.edu/bioinformatics/dfmfiles/files/d/42094/42094.jpg!
